intro: Clinopodium georgianum, commonly known as Georgian mint, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate leaves that have a serrated margin. Its small, tubular flowers are usually purple or blue, arranged in whorls along the stem. The aromatic properties of its leaves make it a valuable plant in traditional medicine and culinary uses.
